papers.paper_title: High-entropy alloys: a review of mechanical properties and deformation mechanisms at cryogenic temperatures

graphs.title: Representative engineering stress–strain curves at different temperatures: CoCrFeMnNi (grain size ≈ 4.4 μm)
graphs.description: Engineering stress (MPa) vs. engineering strain for equiatomic CoCrFeMnNi tested in tension at 77 K, 293 K, 473 K, 673 K, 873 K and 1073 K. Lower temperatures raise yield strength, UTS and ductility; higher temperatures reduce strength and failure strain.
graphs.about_graph: Uniaxial tensile tests of the Cantor alloy across cryogenic to elevated temperatures; curves labeled by temperature. Behavior shows strong temperature dependence with highest work hardening and εf at 77 K.

curves.curve_description: Cryogenic tensile curve with highest σy, σUTS and εf; significant strain hardening up to ~1.0 engineering strain before failure.
curves.about_curve: Exhibits pronounced work hardening and delayed necking at 77 K.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Highest strength and ductility among the set due to cryogenic testing temperature.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, specimen geometry, and engineering axes; all are tension tests.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.030–0.079.

curves.curve_description: Room-temperature curve with lower σy/σUTS and εf than 77 K but still clear strain hardening.
curves.about_curve: Baseline RT behavior for the Cantor alloy.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Intermediate strength/ductility relative to cryogenic and elevated temperatures.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and test configuration; engineering stress–strain.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.030–0.074.

curves.curve_description: Sub-elevated temperature curve with moderate strength and ductility; shows serration-like undulations in the provided image.
curves.about_curve: Thermally softened relative to RT; smaller εf.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lower σUTS and earlier softening compared to 77–293 K curves.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and loading mode.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.124–0.228.

curves.curve_description: Further-reduced strength; limited ductility compared to cryogenic/RT.
curves.about_curve: Shows temperature-induced softening trends.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lower strength level than 473 K; earlier instability.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, tension mode, engineering axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.070.

curves.curve_description: Low strength and moderate ductility; thermal softening evident.
curves.about_curve: Approaches creep-like behavior at high T.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Among the lower strength curves.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same material and axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.077.

curves.curve_description: Lowest strength curve; small work hardening and early softening.
curves.about_curve: High-temperature tensile response.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lowest σy/σUTS and εf of the set.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy/system; engineering stress–strain.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.196–0.326.

graphs.title: Representative engineering stress–strain curves at different temperatures: Al0.1CoCrFeNi
graphs.description: Engineering stress (termed Strength in the figure, MPa) vs. engineering strain (%) in tension at 298 K, 200 K, and 77 K. Labels indicate σy ≈ 250, 295, 412 MPa and σUTS ≈ 635, 745, 1042 MPa at 298, 200, and 77 K, respectively.
graphs.about_graph: Sub-equiatomic Al-containing FCC HEA tested at three temperatures; strong increase in strength and ductility with decreasing temperature.

curves.curve_description: Room-temperature response; σy ~250 MPa, σUTS ~635 MPa; εf ~70–80%.
curves.about_curve: Baseline for comparison to colder tests.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lowest strength and work hardening among the three.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and tensile configuration; engineering axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.219–0.381.

curves.curve_description: Sub-ambient response; σy ~295 MPa, σUTS ~745 MPa; improved hardening vs RT.
curves.about_curve: Intermediate temperature behavior with higher strength and ductility than RT.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Intermediate strength/ductility between 298 K and 77 K.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy; similar test conditions.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.220–0.397.

curves.curve_description: Cryogenic response; σy ~412 MPa, σUTS ~1042 MPa; extended uniform elongation approaching 100%.
curves.about_curve: Highest strength and ductility; pronounced work hardening.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Maximal strength/work hardening due to cryogenic temperature.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same material and engineering axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.023–0.069.

graphs.title: True stress–true strain at ultralow temperatures with in-situ temperature: CrMnFeCoNi
graphs.description: True stress (MPa) vs. true strain for equiatomic CrMnFeCoNi at 295 K, 140 K, and 15 K, with a second (right) y-axis showing specimen temperature (K) during the 15 K test, highlighting serrated flow and self-heating.
graphs.about_graph: Demonstrates cooperative deformation and serrations at 15 K; dual y-axes (stress and temperature).
graphs.y_axis_label: True stress, σ (MPa); secondary axis: Temperature (K) for 15 K test

curves.curve_description: RT response with lower σUTS and εf; no serrations.
curves.about_curve: Dominated by dislocation slip; earlier necking.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lowest strength and no serrated flow.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and true stress–strain measurement.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.074.

curves.curve_description: Higher strength than RT; substantial uniform strain without serrations.
curves.about_curve: Enhanced hardening due to twin activation.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Intermediate strength/ductility between 295 K and 15 K conditions.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, true axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.030–0.071.

curves.curve_description: Ultralow-temperature curve showing very high flow stress (>2 GPa) and pronounced serrated flow; concurrent temperature trace rises from ~10 K to ~20 K.
curves.about_curve: Self-heating and jerky flow observed during deformation at 15 K.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Only curve with serrations and rising temperature during test.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy/system; true stress–strain representation.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.069.

graphs.title: True stress–true strain at ultralow temperatures: CoCrFeNi
graphs.description: True stress (MPa) vs. true strain (%) for equiatomic CoCrFeNi at 295 K, 140 K, 40 K (dashed) and 25 K. Strength increases markedly as temperature decreases; serrations appear at the lowest temperatures.
graphs.about_graph: Demonstrates dramatic cryogenic strengthening and serrated flow onset at ultralow T.

curves.curve_description: Lowest strength curve; early necking relative to colder tests.
curves.about_curve: Baseline RT response.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: No serrations and lowest σUTS.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and test method; true axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.025–0.074.

curves.curve_description: Higher strength and hardening; long uniform strain.
curves.about_curve: Likely TWIP activity; no large serrations.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Intermediate strength between 295 K and 25–40 K.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same material and axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.027–0.076.

curves.curve_description: Near-maximum strength; catastrophic drop at ~60% true strain indicated by dashed magenta curve.
curves.about_curve: Approaches 2.4–2.5 GPa before failure.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Dashed style indicates an additional test; very high strength.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, true axes, ultralow-T regime.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.038–0.074.

curves.curve_description: Highest flow stress with pronounced serrations near the end of deformation.
curves.about_curve: Displays jerky flow at very high stress.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Serrated flow amplitude increases with strain at 25 K.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same material and axes; tension at cryogenic temperatures.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.070.

graphs.title: Compressive stress–strain curves at ultralow temperatures: Al0.5CoCrCuFeNi HEA
graphs.description: Compression stress–strain response at 4.2 K, 7.5 K and 9 K, showing strong cryogenic strengthening with serrated flow; strains reach ~30–35%.
graphs.about_graph: Uniaxial compression in liquid helium regime; serrations reflect intermittent plasticity.

curves.curve_description: Highest stress–strain curve with frequent serrations throughout deformation.
curves.about_curve: Represents lowest temperature compression; strongest serration amplitude.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Highest flow stress and most pronounced serrated flow.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and compression mode; same axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.261–0.292.

curves.curve_description: Slightly lower stress than 4.2 K; serrations persist.
curves.about_curve: Ultralow-T compression with jerky flow.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Intermediate strength among three curves.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and compression setup.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.025–0.073.

curves.curve_description: Lowest stress among the three ultralow-T compression curves; serrations present but smaller.
curves.about_curve: Still exhibits strong hardening with serrated flow.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lowest flow stress in the set.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.079.

papers.paper_title: Engineering atomic-level complexity in high-entropy and complex concentrated alloys

graphs.title: Tensile engineering stress–strain behavior: Ni63.2V36.8 compared with single-phase CCAs (CrCoNi, CrMnFeCoNi)
graphs.description: Engineering stress (MPa) vs. engineering strain (%) at room temperature for a binary Ni–V complex concentrated alloy (Ni63.2V36.8) with ~8.1 μm grains compared against equiatomic CrCoNi (~6.5 μm) and CrMnFeCoNi (~6 μm).
graphs.about_graph: Three tensile engineering stress–strain curves; all single-phase fcc CCAs. The NiV CCA shows higher yield strength and ultimate tensile strength than CrCoNi and CrMnFeCoNi at similar grain sizes.

curves.curve_description: Binary Ni–V CCA tensile curve with high σy (~750 MPa reported in text) and UTS near ~1200 MPa; large uniform elongation (>50%).
curves.about_curve: Single fcc phase verified by high-energy XRD (inset); designed for high solid-solution strength via large electronegativity difference.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Highest yield and UTS among the three despite lower chemical complexity (binary).
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Tension test at room temperature using engineering axes; polycrystalline single-phase fcc microstructures with similar grain sizes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.024–0.075.

curves.curve_description: Medium-entropy alloy tensile curve; lower σy/UTS than NiV but greater than CrMnFeCoNi at similar grain size.
curves.about_curve: Single fcc phase; classic MEA comparison benchmark.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Intermediate strength/ductility among the three.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same test type and axes; similar grain size; single-phase fcc.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.023–0.077.

curves.curve_description: Cantor HEA tensile curve; lowest σy/UTS among the three curves at similar grain size but high ductility.
curves.about_curve: Single fcc phase; widely used HEA reference material.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lowest yield/UTS among the three in this figure.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same tensile testing conditions and engineering axes; single-phase fcc microstructure.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.020–0.071.

papers.paper_title: Towards heterogeneous AlxCoCrFeNi high entropy alloy via friction stir processing

graphs.title: Stress–strain curves of as-cast, FSPed, and FSPed + Al powders specimens
graphs.description: Engineering stress–strain response comparing base alloy, friction-stir processed alloy, and friction-stir processed alloy with added Al powders.
graphs.about_graph: Mini-tensile tests at an initial strain rate of 0.001 s⁻¹ on Al0.1CoCrFeNi alloy conditions. The plot shows engineering stress (MPa) vs engineering strain (mm/mm). FSP increases strength but reduces ductility; adding Al powders further increases strength while maintaining ductility due to heterogeneous structure and Al-rich precipitates.

curves.curve_description: Baseline engineering stress–strain response of as-cast Al0.1CoCrFeNi (single FCC, very coarse grains).
curves.about_curve: Lowest strength; highest ductility among the three, serving as the reference state before processing.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: No grain refinement or second-phase strengthening; therefore lower yield and ultimate strength.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy family and test method/strain rate; engineering stress–strain plotted under identical conditions.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.202–0.338.

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress–strain after friction stir processing (FSP) of the base alloy without additional Al powders.
curves.about_curve: Strength enhanced and ductility reduced compared with as-cast, primarily due to grain refinement (recrystallized FCC ~15 μm).
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Higher yield/UTS than as-cast but lower ductility; lacks Al-rich precipitates/heterogeneous BCC regions seen with Al-powder addition.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same nominal alloy base and testing conditions; engineering stress–strain axes identical.

alloy_composition_in_percentages_corresp._note: Nominal composition Al0.1CoCrFeNi; FSP without added Al powders.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.071.

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress–strain after FSP with Al powders added into predrilled holes, creating localized Al-rich regions.
curves.about_curve: Highest strength with ductility maintained relative to FSP-only due to further grain refinement (~5 μm FCC) and second-phase formation (Al-rich precipitates, BCC Al,Ni-rich regions) yielding a heterogeneous microstructure.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Further strength enhancement and ductility retention from heterogeneous structure and Al-rich precipitates absent in the other two conditions.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same overall alloy system and test method; all curves reflect engineering stress–strain at the same scale.

alloy_composition_in_percentages_corresp._note: Nominal matrix Al0.1CoCrFeNi with localized Al enrichment; exact local at.% not quantified in the figure/caption.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.027–0.069.

papers.paper_title: High strain‑rate compressive deformation behavior of the Al0.1CrFeCoNi high entropy alloy

graphs.title: True stress–true strain curves at different strain rates (compression, room temperature)
graphs.description: Comparison of flow stress response of Al0.1CrFeCoNi under quasi‑static and high strain‑rate compression.
graphs.about_graph: All tests performed at room temperature in compression. Quasi‑static strain rates: 10⁻³, 10⁻², 10⁻¹ s⁻¹; high strain‑rate tests via split Hopkinson pressure bar: ~1000 and ~2600 s⁻¹. Plot shows increasing flow stress with increasing strain rate and significant work hardening across all conditions.

curves.curve_description: Quasi‑static compression at the lowest applied strain rate.
curves.about_curve: Lowest flow stress among all curves; gradual hardening up to ~0.4–0.5 true strain.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lower yield and flow stress due to minimal rate effects; serves as baseline.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, sample geometry, room‑temperature compression, and true stress–true strain axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.028–0.071.

curves.curve_description: Quasi‑static compression at intermediate strain rate.
curves.about_curve: Similar shape to 10⁻³ s⁻¹ with modestly higher flow stress; limited rate sensitivity in quasi‑static regime.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Slightly higher flow stress than 10⁻³ s⁻¹; still below high‑rate curves.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and testing temperature/mode; same axes and scale.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.148–0.218.

curves.curve_description: Quasi‑static compression at the highest quasi‑static rate.
curves.about_curve: Slightly higher yield/flow stress than 10⁻³–10⁻² s⁻¹; pronounced work hardening persists.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Highest flow stress among the quasi‑static set; still below high‑rate curves.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, geometry, and room‑temperature conditions; true stress–true strain plot.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.075.

curves.curve_description: High strain‑rate compression using split Hopkinson pressure bar.
curves.about_curve: Marked increase in yield and flow stress relative to quasi‑static curves; strong rate sensitivity begins to manifest.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Substantially higher stresses than 10⁻³–10⁻¹ s⁻¹ due to phonon‑drag/rate effects.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and temperature; similar hardening trend versus strain.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.074.

curves.curve_description: Highest applied strain rate via split Hopkinson pressure bar.
curves.about_curve: Highest flow stresses across the measured strain range; strong work hardening maintained.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Maximal rate‑induced strengthening among all curves.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, compression mode, room‑temperature testing, and axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.026–0.071.

papers.paper_title: Time-resolved evolution of the deformation mechanisms in a TRIP/TWIP Fe50Mn30Co10Cr10 high entropy alloy during tensile loading probed with synchrotron X-ray diffraction

graphs.title: Engineering & true stress–strain curves with strain-hardening rate (DP-HEA)
graphs.description: Macroscopic tensile response of Fe50Mn30Co10Cr10 (dual-phase TRIP/TWIP HEA) showing engineering and true stress–strain curves; right-hand axis shows strain hardening rate.
graphs.about_graph: Room-temperature tensile test at ~10⁻³ s⁻¹. The blue curve is engineering stress, gray is true stress, and red is the strain-hardening rate dσ/dε (secondary y-axis). Four deformation stages (I–IV) are indicated.
graphs.x_axis_label: Strain (%)  [engineering for blue; true for gray/red]

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress vs engineering strain (blue) for the bulk DP-HEA.
curves.about_curve: Shows macroscopic response; rises to ~700 MPa UTS with ~36% engineering elongation.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Uses engineering definitions (area and strain referenced to original gauge). Values lower than true stress at high strains.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same specimen, temperature, and loading rate as the other curves; derived from the same tensile test.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.020–0.071.

curves.curve_description: True stress vs true strain (gray) computed from the same tensile test.
curves.about_curve: Monotonic hardening to ~900–950 MPa near failure; reflects instantaneous cross‑section and logarithmic strain.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Higher values at large strains compared to engineering curve; represents material flow behavior.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, specimen, and conditions; shares x-axis as true strain (for true-stress and hardening-rate traces).

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.079.

graphs.title: Load partitioning and true stress–true strain (phase-resolved)
graphs.description: Phase-level load sharing between γ‑FCC and ε‑HCP during tension, overlaid with macroscopic true stress–true strain and a theoretical fit.
graphs.about_graph: Phase stresses derived from SXRD lattice strains (Von Mises equivalent) compared against the overall flow curve. Shows how ε‑HCP gradually bears more load as TRIP/TWIP proceed.

curves.curve_description: Bulk flow curve from tensile testing at room temperature.
curves.about_curve: Tracks overall specimen stress; used as reference for partitioning analysis.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Represents total material response rather than a single phase or model.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same strain axis and units; all curves are from the same alloy and experiment.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.074.

curves.curve_description: Model-predicted flow stress (dashed band/black points).
curves.about_curve: Empirical fit (e.g., modified Ludwigson) approximating the measured flow curve.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Not directly measured; derived from constitutive fitting.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same units and axis as the experimental macroscopic curve.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.020–0.079.

curves.curve_description: Von Mises equivalent phase stress for ε‑HCP (red circles).
curves.about_curve: Shows higher stress carrying capacity that increases with strain as TRIP forms more ε‑HCP and TWIP/twinning activates.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Phase-resolved; typically above γ‑FCC at a given strain.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Derived from the same SXRD-based lattice strain analysis and test conditions.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.074.

curves.curve_description: Von Mises equivalent phase stress for γ‑FCC (blue circles).
curves.about_curve: Lower stress level than ε‑HCP at higher strains; γ‑FCC yields early and contributes via TRIP and dislocation slip.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Phase-resolved stress of the ductile matrix phase.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same units and extraction method as ε‑HCP phase stress.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.020–0.079.

curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, grain size, temperature, and test geometry; true stress–true strain reported.

alloy_composition_in_percentages_corresp._note: Exact at.% not specified in the figure; composition reported as Al0.3 with Co, Cr, Fe, Ni near-equiatomic.

curves.curve_description: True stress–true strain at 10¹ s⁻¹ for 12 μm grains.
curves.about_curve: Intermediate rate; higher flow stresses than 10⁻³ s⁻¹ with similar hardening shape.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Elevated flow stress vs quasi-static; below the dynamic curve.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Identical alloy and test temperature; same axes and scale.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.026–0.075.

curves.curve_description: Split-Hopkinson pressure bar rate for 12 μm grains.
curves.about_curve: Highest rate; highest flow stresses among the three curves; shortened strain range typical of SHPB data.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Maximum rate-induced strengthening.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same specimen condition and temperature; true stress vs true strain.

graphs.title: True stress–true strain at multiple strain rates (d₂ = 150 μm, 60CR+HM60min)
graphs.description: Mechanical response of coarse-grained Al0.3CoCrFeNi (150 μm) under quasi-static (10⁻³ s⁻¹), intermediate (10¹ s⁻¹), and dynamic (2×10³ s⁻¹) loading.
graphs.about_graph: Room-temperature tests across three strain-rate regimes after 60% cold rolling + 60 min solutionizing; single-phase FCC. Panel corresponds to Fig. 3(b) in the paper.

curves.curve_description: True stress–true strain at 10⁻³ s⁻¹ for 150 μm grains.

graphs.title: Engineering stress–strain curves for as-cast and as-FSP Cu-HEA (As-cast, S350, S150, D-pass)
graphs.description: Room-temperature tensile engineering stress–strain behavior for Fe38.5Mn20Co20Cr15Si5Cu1.5 (Cu-HEA) in as-cast and three friction-stir processed conditions (single pass 350 RPM, single pass 150 RPM, and double pass).
graphs.about_graph: Specimens tested at ~10⁻³ s⁻¹. Friction stir processing (FSP) refines grains and alters γ→ε TRIP behavior, raising strength while maintaining ductility; D-pass shows the best strength–ductility balance.

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress–strain of the as-cast Cu-HEA (coarse-grained γ with limited TRIP).
curves.about_curve: Lowest strength; moderate ductility; serves as baseline before FSP.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Coarser grains and Cu–Mn phase separation; lowest UTS among the four.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy chemistry and tensile test conditions; engineering definitions and units identical.

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress–strain after one FSP pass at 350 RPM (grain-refined γ).
curves.about_curve: Higher strength than as-cast due to refinement; ductility remains good.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Intermediate strength/ductility between S150 and D-pass; process parameters differ.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and strain rate; engineering stress–strain plotted on same axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.023–0.076.

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress–strain after one FSP pass at 150 RPM.

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress–strain after two overlapping FSP passes (350 RPM then 150 RPM).

curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Bimodal grain structure from double pass; superior strength–ductility among all states.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and test settings; engineering curve on same axes.

graphs.title: Engineering stress–engineering strain curves for Cu-HEA in all rolled conditions (R1, R2, R3)
graphs.description: Room-temperature tensile engineering stress–strain response of Fe38.5Mn20Co20Cr15Si5Cu1.5 (Cu-HEA) after sequential rolling: R1 (hot rolled, 6.5 mm), R2 (warm rolled, 3.15 mm), and R3 (cold rolled, 2.03 mm).
graphs.about_graph: All curves measured at an initial strain rate of 10⁻³ s⁻¹. R3 exhibits a massively interfaced γ/ε microstructure leading to ~1.5 GPa YS and ~1.95 GPa UTS (true UTS ~2.2 GPa), with ε phase fraction increasing during straining, as indicated by insets.

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress–strain for the hot-rolled condition (6.5 mm).
curves.about_curve: Lowest strength; γ-dominated, relatively coarse microstructure.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Shows the lowest yield and ultimate strengths among the three states.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy composition, specimen geometry, room-temperature test, and engineering definitions.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.025–0.075.

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress–strain for the warm-rolled condition (3.15 mm).
curves.about_curve: Intermediate strength and work hardening relative to R1 and R3.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Strengthened versus R1 due to additional refinement; below R3 which is heavily interfaced.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and testing conditions; engineering stress–strain plotted on identical axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.078.

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress–strain for the cold-rolled condition (2.03 mm) with massively interfaced γ/ε microstructure.
curves.about_curve: Highest strength and work hardening; ε phase fraction increases markedly with strain (from ~48% to ~93% insets).
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Exhibits the highest YS (~1.5 GPa) and UTS (~1.95 GPa eng.; ~2.2 GPa true) due to massive interface strengthening and delayed TRIP activation.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy chemistry and test protocol; engineering stress vs engineering strain.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.023–0.074.

graphs.title: Engineering stress–strain curves: CR-R vs CR-R-600/150h vs CR-R-800/0.5h
graphs.description: Quasi-static tensile tests (~1e-3 s^-1) comparing the base recrystallized condition (CR-R) with two precipitation-annealed conditions (600°C/150h and 800°C/0.5h).
graphs.about_graph: Precipitation of coherent L12 (γ′) markedly raises strength in CR-R-600 and CR-R-800. CR-R shows the greatest elongation (~65%), while CR-R-600 reaches ~1.1 GPa UTS with ~25% elongation and CR-R-800 ~20%.

curves.about_curve: Lowest strength; highest ductility (~65% engineering strain). Smooth work hardening.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Much lower yield/UTS; broader strain to failure.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy family, specimen geometry, room temperature, quasi-static rate.

curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same testing protocol and axes; same base composition.

curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, temperature, and strain rate; engineering definition.

graphs.title: Indentation stress–strain curves for different austenite (c-f.c.c.) grain orientations
graphs.description: Nanoindentation (sphero-conical indenter, 5 μm tip radius) stress–strain response measured inside single c-f.c.c. grains oriented along {111}, {110}, and {100}. Curves show incipient plasticity and subsequent hardening up to ~0.06 strain with stresses approaching 2.5–2.7 GPa.
graphs.about_graph: Each panel corresponds to a different crystallographic orientation of the c-f.c.c. phase. Indentation curves were derived from load–depth data using the Pathak–Kalidindi spherical-equivalence method; all tests were performed at room temperature on the same HEA sample after 800 °C/30 min anneal.

curves.curve_description: Indentation stress–strain from a c-f.c.c. grain oriented near {111}; shows the lowest yield among the three and strong work hardening to ~2.6–2.7 GPa by ~0.06 strain.
curves.about_curve: This curve reflects ease of slip on close-packed {111} planes, giving the lowest nanoindentation yield stress and highest TRIP propensity reported for this orientation.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lower incipient plasticity stress and slightly higher terminal stress; orientation is {111} instead of {110}/{100}.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, same 5 μm sphero-conical tip, identical test conditions and analysis protocol; all show elastic–plastic transition followed by hardening.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.062.

curves.curve_description: Indentation stress–strain from a c-f.c.c. grain oriented near {110}; yield occurs at higher stress than {111} with comparable hardening towards ~2.5 GPa.
curves.about_curve: Intermediate orientation response; effective modulus and yield are between those of {111} and {100}.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Higher incipient plasticity stress than {111} and slightly different hardening slope; orientation is {110}.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same material/indenter/analysis; similar qualitative elastic–plastic transition and rising stress with strain.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.023–0.063.

curves.curve_description: Indentation stress–strain from a c-f.c.c. grain oriented near {100}; displays the highest incipient plasticity stress among the three with hardening to ~2.3–2.5 GPa.
curves.about_curve: Least favorable slip geometry results in the highest nanoindentation yield stress and slightly lower effective modulus than {111}/{110}.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Highest yield stress and somewhat lower early hardening rate; orientation is {100}.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same HEA, tip radius, and testing/processing history; same method to convert load–depth to indentation stress–strain.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.065.

graphs.title: Engineering and true strain–stress curves and strain hardening rate at 1×10^-3 s^-1 (room temperature)
graphs.description: Macroscopic tensile response of the as-cast metastable Fe42Mn28Co10Cr15Si5 HEA. Plot shows engineering and true stress–strain curves plus the instantaneous strain-hardening rate. Regions A–D mark distinct deformation regimes (elastic/slip, onset of TRIP, TRIP+TWIP, and multiple twinning at higher strain).
graphs.about_graph: Three curves: engineering stress–strain (black), true stress–strain (red), and strain hardening rate (blue, right axis). Green dashed lines indicate transitions between regimes A–D.
graphs.x_axis_label: Strain [%] (engineering for black curve; true for red and for hardening-rate partitioning)
graphs.y_axis_label: Stress [MPa] (left axis); Strain hardening rate [MPa] (right axis)

curves.curve_description: Conventional engineering stress vs engineering strain response of the bulk specimen.
curves.about_curve: Used for comparison with true stress; lower than true stress at larger strains due to area change.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Uses original cross-section (engineering measure); does not reflect instantaneous area so it underestimates stress at higher strain compared to the true curve; not a derivative like the hardening rate.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same material, test temperature, and global deformation regimes A–D; all captured from the same tensile test.

curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same specimen and loading rate; reflects the same stage boundaries as engineering curve and hardening rate.

curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Uses same axes and reflects the same deformation regimes.

curves.about_curve: Carries notably more load than γ-f.c.c.; overtakes after yielding and dominates at higher strain.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Phase-specific; reflects TRIP-generated fraction increase and TWIP activation.

graphs.title: Phase stress partitioning during in‑situ synchrotron tensile loading
graphs.description: Partitioned phase stresses for FCC and B2 BCC phases compared to macroscopic and rule‑of‑mixtures responses.
graphs.about_graph: Using in‑situ high‑energy XRD, stresses carried by disordered FCC and ordered B2 BCC phases were computed; the macroscopic curve and ROM combination are also shown.

curves.curve_description: Partitioned stress borne by the disordered FCC phase (blue).
curves.about_curve: Softer phase; yields first (~320–350 MPa) and exhibits minimal hardening.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lower modulus/yield; smaller stress increase after yielding than B2 BCC.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Calculated from the same in‑situ diffraction dataset for the same alloy.

curves.about_curve: Harder phase; yields later (~900 MPa partitioned stress) and hardens strongly.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Much larger stress increase with strain; primary contributor to macroscopic hardening.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same test and analysis method; stresses referenced to macroscopic strain.

curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Built from the same phase stresses and phase fractions of the alloy.

graphs.description: Figure 1: True stress vs. true strain curves for S1, S2, S3, S4 categories compressed to fracture in in-plane (IP/TD) and through-thickness (TT/ND) directions, plus a tension curve along RD for S3.

papers.paper_title: Role of TiB2 inoculation particles during welding of a AlCoCrFeNi high entropy alloy

graphs.title: Representative tensile test results (BM vs welded joints with and without TiB2 inoculation)
graphs.description: Macroscopic engineering stress–strain response comparing base material (BM), a gas–tungsten-arc welded joint without TiB2 inoculants, and a welded joint inoculated with TiB2 particles.
graphs.about_graph: The plot shows that conventional GTAW welding without TiB2 increases UTS relative to BM, while TiB2 inoculation decreases macroscopic ductility and UTS due to strain localization in HAZ. Reported UTS/elongation (approx.): BM ≈ 877 MPa @ ~12%, Weld (no TiB2) ≈ 1140 MPa @ ~12%, Weld (TiB2) ≈ 667 MPa @ ~5%.

curves.curve_description: As-cast AlCoCrFeNi HEA tensile curve.
curves.about_curve: Lower UTS than welded (no TiB2) but higher than TiB2-inoculated joint; moderate ductility.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: No weld-induced heterogeneity; curve lacks the higher initial work hardening seen in the non-inoculated weld.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy family and testing setup; engineering stress–strain in MPa vs %.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.078.

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress–strain of the GTAW joint without inoculants.
curves.about_curve: Highest UTS among the three; ductility ~12%; fracture near HAZ/FZ interface.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Shows the largest macroscopic strength due to refined FZ without TiB2; composition in FZ enriched in Cr with lower Al and Ni compared to BM.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same specimen geometry and test rate; same units and plotting style.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.077.

curves.curve_description: Engineering stress–strain of the GTAW joint inoculated with TiB2 particles.
curves.about_curve: Lower UTS and elongation because deformation localizes in the softer HAZ; FZ is strongest/hardest region.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Only curve influenced by Ti carryover from partial TiB2 dissolution; macroscopic response drops despite locally strong FZ.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy base system and testing protocol.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.051.

graphs.title: Comparison of mechanical responses under quasi-static and high strain-rate conditions
graphs.description: True stress–true strain response of the AlCoCrFeNi2.1 eutectic high-entropy alloy comparing quasi-static loading with high strain-rate loading (SHPB).
graphs.about_graph: Both curves show continuous work hardening up to ~0.2 true strain; the SHPB (high strain-rate) curve exhibits higher flow stress than the quasi-static curve across the measured strain range.

curves.curve_description: Quasi-static loading; nominal strain rate ~1e-3 s^-1. Flow stress rises from ~750 MPa at small strain to ~1.1–1.2 GPa by ~0.2 true strain.
curves.about_curve: Represents baseline response; lower flow stress than SHPB, similar hardening trend.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lower flow stress across the entire strain range compared to the SHPB curve.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and overall work-hardening character; both are true stress–true strain curves from uniaxial loading.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.079.

curves.curve_description: Split Hopkinson Pressure Bar (SHPB) high strain-rate loading; nominal strain rate ~1e3 s^-1. Flow stress ≳100 MPa higher than quasi-static over the same strain window; approaches ~1.4–1.5 GPa by ~0.2 true strain.
curves.about_curve: Demonstrates rate strengthening while maintaining pronounced work hardening.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Higher flow stress due to high strain-rate loading; greater hardening slope at low strains.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, same axes/units, and similarly smooth hardening without serrations in the plotted range.

graphs.title: Tensile engineering stress–strain at 77 K for B-doped Fe40Mn40Co10Cr10 (at%) HEA at different strain rates
graphs.description: Engineering stress σ (MPa) vs. engineering strain ε for an interstitially hardened, fcc single-phase Fe40Mn40Co10Cr10 (at%) HEA tested in tension at 77 K. Curves correspond to low (HEA-L), moderate (HEA-M), and high (HEA-H) strain rates; σYS (0.2% offset), σUTS, and εf indicated. Aged state (773 K/360 min/furnace cool) for HEA-L and HEA-M; recrystallized (1073 K/60 min/water quench) for HEA-H.
graphs.about_graph: All three curves show steep initial hardening followed by broad work-hardening to plateaus. Higher strain rate increases σUTS and total elongation with negligible change in σYS. Grain size across samples ~3.5–5.1 μm.

curves.about_curve: B-doped, fcc single-phase; tension at 77 K under quasistatic conditions; similar grain size (~3.5–5.1 μm).
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lowest σUTS and elongation among the three due to lowest strain rate.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy composition, test temperature (77 K), engineering axes, and comparable grain size.

curves.about_curve: Same heat-treated state as HEA-L; measured at 77 K with quasistatic loading.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Higher σUTS and ductility than HEA-L due to higher strain rate; below HEA-H.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Identical alloy and temperature; engineering stress–strain axes; similar grain size.

graphs.title: True stress–true strain curves of AlCrFeCoNiCu and CrFeCoNiCu alloys under compression
graphs.description: Room-temperature compression curves comparing AlCrFeCoNiCu vs. CrFeCoNiCu. Adding Al (equimolar system) dramatically raises the yield stress (~1147 MPa vs. ~237 MPa for the Al-free alloy) and the Al-bearing curve shows a peak ≈1.6 GPa followed by fracture near ~20% strain, while the CrFeCoNiCu curve did not fracture within the plotted strain range.
graphs.about_graph: Both curves are from compression tests performed at room temperature on HEA systems discussed in the paper. The key microstructural distinction driving the mechanical response is the formation of a NiAl (B2) intermetallic phase in AlCrFeCoNiCu (with (α-Fe,Cr) solid solution and Cu-rich precipitates), whereas CrFeCoNiCu remains a solid solution; this multiphase strengthening explains the much higher strength of the Al-containing alloy.

curves.curve_description: True stress–true strain under compression at room temperature for the Al-containing HEA. Yield stress ≈1147 MPa; peak stress ≈1600 MPa; fracture near ~20% strain.
curves.about_curve: Al addition leads to phase decomposition forming a NiAl (B2) intermetallic plus (α-Fe,Cr) solid solution and Cu-rich precipitates, which significantly increases strength compared to the Al-free alloy.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Much higher yield and flow stresses and it fractures within the plotted strain window (~20%).
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same test mode (compression), temperature (room temperature), axes (true stress vs. true strain), and general HEA family.

alloy_composition_in_percentages_corresp._note: Nominal composition reported as equimolar in the paper.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.078.

curves.about_curve: Single-phase solid-solution response without the NiAl intermetallic; exhibits lower strength and continuous hardening.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Substantially lower yield/flow stresses; does not fracture within the displayed strain range.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same test conditions and axes; both are multi-principal-element alloys from the same study.

The TaNbHfZrTi curve shows high strain hardening and large ductility; the other two exhibit lower ductility and earlier softening.
graphs.about_graph: Compression tests at room temperature; axes are engineering strain (%) on x and engineering stress (MPa) on y, as labeled in the figure. The black curve (TaNbHfZrTi) extends to ~40% strain with strong work hardening; the red (TaNbWMoV) and purple (TaNbWMo) curves peak near ~10–12% strain with lower ductility. These trends are consistent with the paper’s discussion of high strength and ductility for TaNbHfZrTi. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

graphs.title: Engineering stress–strain (fine-grained, d ≈ 4.4 μm) at six temperatures
graphs.description: Representative engineering stress–strain curves for the fine-grained CoCrFeMnNi alloy tested at 77, 293, 473, 673, 873, and 1073 K at an engineering strain rate of 10^-3 s^-1. Highest strength and ductility at 77 K; pronounced serrations at intermediate temperatures; a clear yield point with a small load drop is observed around 293–473 K; at 1073 K, the maximum stress is reached at low strain but failure occurs at >60% strain.
graphs.about_graph: Quasi-static uniaxial tension on recrystallized, single-phase fcc CoCrFeMnNi with grain size ≈4.4 μm. Curves show strong temperature dependence of yield strength, UTS, and elongation; the inset for 473 K highlights a small load drop after yielding. Test rate 10^-3 s^-1 and the six temperatures are annotated on the curves.

graphs.description: Engineering stress–strain curves at room temperature comparing a TRIP-assisted dual-phase high-entropy alloy (Fe50Mn30Co10Cr10, f.c.c. + h.c.p.) with grain sizes of ~45 μm (as-homogenized) and ~4.5 μm (grain-refined) against single-phase f.c.c. HEAs: Fe37Mn45Co9Cr9 with ~90 μm and ~6 μm grains, and Fe20Mn20Ni20Co20Cr20 (equiatomic, from ref. 6).
graphs.about_graph: Demonstrates the strength–ductility improvements obtainable by metastability engineering (TRIP) and grain refinement in high-entropy alloys. Units are Engineering stress (MPa) vs. Engineering strain (%).

curves.curve_description: As-homogenized dual-phase alloy with ~45 μm grain size.
curves.about_curve: Represents the metastable dual-phase (f.c.c. matrix with h.c.p. transformation, TRIP-active) condition.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Dual-phase constitution and coarser grains versus the grain-refined TRIP-DP-HEA; different composition and phase content versus single-phase HEAs.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Room-temperature uniaxial tensile test; engineering stress–strain representation; same axes and units; Fe-based high-entropy alloy family.

curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Room-temperature uniaxial tensile test; engineering stress–strain representation; same axes and units; Fe-based high-entropy alloy family.

curves.about_curve: Curve lies between 47 h and 4 h in both strength and elongation.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Middle performance; no extreme rise in WHR.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and test setup.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.072.

curves.curve_description: Finer, closely spaced L12; strongly suppresses martensite during quench and delays deformation-induced martensite.
curves.about_curve: Higher uniform strain but lower YS/UTS than 47 h; gentle work hardening.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lowest YS/UTS among the three; most suppressed transformation.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Identical composition and testing protocol.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.217–0.269.

graphs.title: True stress–strain: FNAT-47h vs FNAT-4h
graphs.description: True stress–strain curves at room temperature for 47 h and 4 h aged conditions; paired with WHR plot in the paper.
graphs.about_graph: Shows much stronger work hardening in 47 h (due to deformation-induced martensite) versus smoother hardening in 4 h.

curves.curve_description: Exhibits sharp WHR rise after a few percent strain, reaching ~2+ GPa true stress.
curves.about_curve: Demonstrates TRIP-assisted hardening triggered by precipitate spacing.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Higher true stress and pronounced hardening peak.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same base alloy and temperature.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.022–0.078.

curves.curve_description: Smoother hardening to ~1.9–2.0 GPa true stress with delayed/limited martensite formation.
curves.about_curve: Reflects stronger spatial confinement from finer precipitates.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: No sharp WHR spike; overall lower true stress at a given strain.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Identical chemistry and test conditions.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.024–0.079.

graphs.title: Engineering stress–strain: FNAT solutionized at 1100 °C + water quench
graphs.description: Room-temperature curve used by the authors to estimate the fcc-matrix yield strength (~325 MPa).
graphs.about_graph: Baseline solutionized state without ageing; used for rule-of-mixtures estimate of FNAT-47h YS.

curves.curve_description: Single curve; smooth hardening to ~650–680 MPa before necking; 0.2% offset YS ~325 MPa.
curves.about_curve: Represents fcc matrix without precipitate strengthening.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: N/A—only one curve in this graph.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Room-temperature tensile test; same alloy family.

alloy_composition_in_percentages_corresp.note: Analyzed at% (post-casting) reported by authors; Fe given as ~balance.

papers.paper_title: Effect of carbon on cryogenic tensile behavior of CoCrFeMnNi-type high-entropy alloys

graphs.title: Tensile engineering stress–strain at 293 K for CoCr0.25FeMnNi with x = 0–2 at.% C
graphs.description: Room-temperature (293 K) engineering stress–strain curves for CoCr0.25FeMnNi HEAs with carbon contents x = 0, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 at.%. Strength increases with carbon; ductility decreases modestly.
graphs.about_graph: All specimens tested at the same nominal strain rate; inset shows serrations at RT for C-containing alloys.

curves.curve_description: Baseline alloy without intentional carbon; extensive strain hardening and high UE.
curves.about_curve: Lowest YS/UTS among the four at 293 K; smooth curve with minimal serrations.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lowest strength; highest ductility at RT.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same base composition and test conditions; single-phase fcc matrix.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.028–0.077.

curves.curve_description: Carbon in solid solution increases YS/UTS; small serrations observed at RT.
curves.about_curve: Intermediate strength–ductility balance; curve lies above x = 0.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Higher YS/UTS than x = 0 with slight ductility reduction.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Identical specimen geometry and test method.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.032–0.072.

curves.curve_description: Further solid-solution strengthening with modest ductility drop.
curves.about_curve: Curve shifts to higher stress across the strain range vs. x = 0.5.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Higher strength than x = 0.5; similar shape.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy family and RT test.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.071.

curves.curve_description: Highest strength at RT; slight carbides (<1 vol%) may be present; ductility lowest of the set but still substantial.
curves.about_curve: Topmost curve; clear strengthening vs. lower-C states.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Maximum YS/UTS; most pronounced serrations at RT.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same testing protocol and base element ratios (CoCr0.25FeMnNi).

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.077.

graphs.title: Tensile engineering stress–strain at 77 K for CoCr0.25FeMnNi with x = 0–2 at.% C
graphs.description: Cryogenic (77 K) engineering stress–strain curves. Lower temperature substantially raises strength at every carbon level; ductility generally increases except at the highest C.
graphs.about_graph: Same specimen geometry and nominal strain rate; no serrations at 77 K in these curves.

curves.curve_description: Large increase in YS/UTS vs. RT with high uniform elongation.
curves.about_curve: Lowest strength among cryogenic curves but markedly above RT x = 0.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lowest cryogenic strength; highest cryogenic ductility.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Identical alloy family and test temperature (77 K).

curves.about_curve: Second from bottom at cryogenic temperature.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Intermediate strength–ductility at 77 K.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy system; same cooling and test protocol.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.233–0.366.

curves.curve_description: Further increase in YS/UTS; work-hardening remains high.
curves.about_curve: Second from top at cryogenic temperature.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Higher strength than x = 0.5 at 77 K with similar curve shape.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same HEA and strain rate.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.033–0.079.

curves.curve_description: Highest cryogenic strength (YS and UTS); ductility does not increase vs. RT at this C level.
curves.about_curve: Topmost curve at 77 K.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Maximum strength among all conditions; EF/UE comparatively lower than other 77 K curves.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same processing route; same cryogenic testing conditions.

papers.paper_title: Structure and mechanical properties of a light-weight AlNbTiV high entropy alloy

graphs.title: Stress–strain compression curves of the AlNbTiV alloy at given temperatures
graphs.description: Compression true stress–true strain curves for an equiatomic AlNbTiV alloy measured at 20°C, 600°C, 800°C and 1000°C.
graphs.about_graph: Single alloy (AlNbTiV) tested in compression at different temperatures; the figure shows temperature-dependent strength and work-hardening/softening.

curves.curve_description: Room-temperature compression response; high peak stress followed by noticeable softening.
curves.about_curve: Shows the highest initial yield/peak stress (~1300 MPa) with a drop after ~6–8% strain, typical of flow softening in compression at RT.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Highest strength; shows post-peak softening unlike the high-temperature curves that harden or remain flat.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and test mode; same axes and units; all curves start with rapid stress rise at small strain.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.024–0.079.

curves.curve_description: Elevated-temperature compression response with lower strength than RT and modest softening at larger strains.
curves.about_curve: Peak stress around ~1000 MPa with some softening by ~12–15% strain.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Intermediate strength; transition behaviour between RT softening and 800°C hardening.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, same testing mode and units; temperature is the only controlled variable.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.078.

curves.curve_description: High-temperature compression response characterized by continuous work hardening with strain.
curves.about_curve: Stress increases steadily from ~800 MPa to ~1200 MPa up to ~40% strain, indicative of dynamic hardening at 800°C.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Unlike 20°C and 600°C curves, it shows pronounced monotonic hardening without a peak/softening.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and axes; temperature is the distinguishing condition across curves.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.026–0.079.

curves.curve_description: Very high-temperature compression response with low flow stress and nearly flat work-hardening.
curves.about_curve: Flow stress is lowest (~150–250 MPa) and varies weakly with strain up to ~40%.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lowest strength; minimal hardening; reflects high-temperature softening mechanisms.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Identical material and test type; axes/units unchanged; only temperature differs.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.024–0.078.

papers.paper_title: Strong and ductile CoCrFeNi high-entropy alloy microfibers at ambient and cryogenic temperatures

graphs.title: Engineering tensile stress–strain curves of CoCrFeNi microfibers (293 K, 150 K)
graphs.description: Engineering stress (MPa) vs engineering strain (%) for as-drawn microfiber at 293 K and annealed microfibers at 293 K and 150 K; bulk CoCrFeNi (annealed) shown for comparison.
graphs.about_graph: Annealed microfibers show much higher strength than bulk, and cryogenic (150 K) testing yields both higher strength and larger uniform elongation than 293 K. Initial as-drawn microfiber is very strong but brittle.

curves.curve_description: As-drawn CoCrFeNi microfiber tested at 293 K (very high strength, negligible ductility).
curves.about_curve: Tensile strength about 1.7 GPa with brittle behavior due to high defect density from cold drawing.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Highest initial strength but essentially no plasticity; contrasts with annealed curves that show significant ductility.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy composition and fiber geometry; same engineering stress–strain axes.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.880–1.044.

curves.curve_description: Engineering curve of annealed CoCrFeNi microfiber at 293 K.
curves.about_curve: YS ≈ 600 MPa, UTS ≈ 1066 MPa, UE ≈ 42%; visible necking after fracture.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lower strength and ductility than the 150 K annealed curve; much more ductile than the initial as-drawn curve.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and specimen size; measured under uniaxial tension.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 2.774–3.307.

curves.curve_description: Engineering curve of annealed CoCrFeNi microfiber at 150 K.
curves.about_curve: YS ≈ 1010 MPa, UTS ≈ 1454 MPa, UE ≈ 75%; higher strength and ductility than at 293 K; pronounced necking.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Highest combination of strength and ductility among annealed conditions; shows sustained work hardening.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy/system and axes; uniaxial tensile test.

Kocks–Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 2.887–3.654.

curves.curve_description: Engineering curve from literature for bulk annealed CoCrFeNi; included in figure for comparison.

curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Represents bulk (not microfiber); generally lower strength.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy base and tensile testing concept; engineering stress–strain axes.

graphs.title: Engineering compression stress–strain at 23 °C for TaNbHfZrTi vs. TaNbWMoV and TaNbWMo

graphs.about_graph: The equiatomic quinary TaNbHfZrTi alloy shows strong work hardening and large compressive ductility compared with the refractory HEAs from ref. [13].
